awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Computational Fluid Dynamics Software for Quantum Computers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to utilize quantum computing to perform computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations, initially to solve problems in the aerospace and automotive industries. The technology may also play a vital role in national defense, as CFD is critical in designing aircraft, missiles, armored vehicles, and naval systems. Subsequently, the product will find many other industrial applications, including healthcare applications, such as simulating blood flow in organs or airflow in the lungs. The product will help companies to reduce the cost and time in developing superior technologies, such as safer aircraft that consume less fuel, energy plants that emit less carbon dioxide (CO2), and devices that deliver drugs more effectively. The project includes a partnership between academic and industrial researchers. By involving student interns and exposing them to the emerging field of quantum computing, this project aims to contribute to science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) workforce development. Ultimately, this project aims to create a new generation of CFD technology based on quantum computing, advancing the CFD field, and aiding U.S. leadership in quantum computing.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop a new CFD technology for quantum computers. CFD is a valuable tool for engineers to predict fluid flow and design or troubleshoot various systems such as airplanes, automobiles, and chemical reactors. However, some CFD simulations are too expensive or impossible to run, even though such knowledge could save hundreds of millions of dollars in certifying each new aircraft type. High resolution slows CFD simulations because large amounts of data must be stored in, read from, and written to the computer memory. This limitation can be overcome by utilizing the vast quantum state spaces that have become available with the introduction of quantum computers. An algorithm will be implemented in a software prototype and the flow between fixed and moving plates will be simulated on quantum computers. A performance metric estimated from the simulation results will assess the potential for achieving a quantum advantage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
QubitSolve is dedicated to harnessing the power of quantum computers to solve the partial differential equations that form the basis of computational fluid dynamics (CFD). This breakthrough will allow CFD simulations that are currently too slow or impossible to run on traditional computers. These simulations have the potential to bring about substantial economic advantages by helping companies create superior products more efficiently and at a reduced cost.

CFD is an engineering tool that predicts fluid flow in or around devices by solving a set of partial differential equations called Navier-Stokes equations. CFD is used in applications such as designing airplanes and automobiles, scaling up chemical reactors, and predicting ocean flow around offshore drilling platforms. In the past, the engineering process consisted of cycles of designing, building, and testing. However, this process was slow and expensive. In the last forty years, CFD has transformed that process into cycles of designing and simulating, followed by building and testing. Thus, CFD simulations enable companies to reduce the cost and time involved in developing technology, giving them a competitive advantage.

However, some CFD simulations are too expensive or impossible to run, even though the insights gained could save hundreds of millions of dollars, such as in certifying new aircraft types. These simulations require a classical computer to store and manipulate large amounts of data. As the size of the simulation increases, the simulation becomes slow due to increased memory traffic or even impossible because the classical computer runs out of memory. This limitation can be overcome by utilizing the vast quantum state spaces that have become available with the introduction of quantum computers.

QubitSolve is at the forefront of developing next-generation CFD technology that harnesses the power of quantum computers. In this approach, classical and quantum computers work in tandem to perform the CFD simulation. Classical computers handle small data sets with minimal computational time, while quantum computers manage large data sets and process them rapidly. This innovative method not only has the potential to perform simulations previously considered too slow or impossible on classical computers but also opens up new possibilities for CFD, transforming the field.

In this Phase I SBIR project, we have made significant progress in bringing our approach closer to commercialization.

We have reached a significant milestone in our project by successfully executing our algorithm on a quantum simulator. This groundbreaking achievement demonstrates that the partial differential equations that form the backbone of CFD can indeed be solved on quantum computers. To our knowledge, no CFD software that runs on quantum computers has been developed. Our demonstration is the first to offer a practical quantum solution for CFD, marking a new era of innovation in this field.

We have reached another milestone in estimating the simulation size beyond which quantum CFD will surpass classical CFD. We conducted simulations on IonQ and IBM quantum computers, collected performance data, and compared the performance of classical and quantum CFD. We estimated the performance improvements required in the quantum CFD to surpass classical CFD in industrial applications of CFD. Our comparison is unprecedented.

Over the next two years, we will gather additional data, enhance our algorithm, and create a minimum viable product that meets our customers' requirements.

The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is significant. Our technology will initially address CFD challenges in the aerospace, defense, and automotive industries. It will have implications for national defense, as CFD is crucial in the design of aircraft, missiles, armored vehicles, and naval systems. Later, our technology will also address CFD challenges in other industries, including chemicals, energy, and healthcare. Our solution will enable companies to reduce the time and cost required to develop superior products, such as safer aircraft with lower fuel consumption, energy plants emitting less carbon dioxide, and more effective drug delivery devices. The project involved a collaboration between academic and industrial researchers and provided hands-on experience with quantum computing to two computer science seniors working as interns. Ultimately, developing a new generation of CFD technology based on quantum computing will advance the field and contribute to U.S. leadership in quantum computing.

 


Last Modified: 05/21/2024
Modified by: Madhava Syamlal

Image
  • Beyond a certain simulation size, quantum CFD surpasses classical CFD and enables simulations that are too slow or impossible to perform. Although the chart does not show real data or the current state of quantum CFD, it is based on our findings and the performance we expect to achieve.
    Madhava Syamlal
    Copyrighted
    Madhava Syamlal
    Classical CFD vs Quantum CFD
